src:
Socio de ‘abohámster’ de Uribe también habría visitado cárceles por caso del expresidente
Se trata de Juan José Salazar Cruz, que respaldó la versión del jurista Diego Cadena de que los pagos que este hizo a un exparamilitar fueron humanitarios.

05 Nov 2019, 06:46

Por eso mismo, la Fiscalía citó a Salazar para que explique las transacciones que se le hicieron al exparamilitar Carlos Enrique Vélez, conocido en las Autodefensas como ‘Victor’, que según Cadena fueron de 2 millones de pesos, informó El Tiempo.
Asimismo, de acuerdo con el diario, el socio de Cadena, que es el representante legal suplente de la firma del jurista de Uribe, “aparece haciendo varias gestiones en cárceles”. No obstante, se desconoce qué propósito habría tenido el socio del autodenominado ‘abohámster’ con esas visitas.
Por otra parte, otro hombre identificado como Rodolfo Echeverry hizo consignaciones a favor de testigos, asegura el periódico, que no especifica qué relación tendría Echeverry con Cadena o con el propio senador Uribe.
Cabe mencionar que este fin de semana, Cadena regresó al país, luego de irse a Miami, Estados Unidos, para otra indagatoria ante la Fiscalía, en la que, de acuerdo con RCN Radio, presentará pruebas nuevas para demostrar su inocencia ante los señalamientos de sobornar al exparamilitar Vélez para que este cambiara su testimonio en un caso que vincula al expresidente.
La cita del abogado al servicio el ahora senador será este martes a las 9:00 de la mañana.
text:
Partner of ‘abohámster’ of Uribe would also have visited prisons in case of the former president
This is Juan José Salazar Cruz, who supported the lawyer Diego Cadena's version that the payments he made to an exparamilitar were humanitarian.

05 Nov 2019, 06:46

For this reason, the Prosecutor's Office summoned Salazar to explain the transactions that were made to him to expand Carlos Enrique Vélez, known in the Self-Defense Groups as ‘Victor’, which according to Cadena was 2 million pesos, El Tiempo reported.
Also, according to the newspaper, the partner of Cadena, who is the legal representative of the Uribe jurist's firm, "appears to be doing several steps in prisons." However, it is unknown what the self-styled partner ‘abohámster’ would have had with these visits.
On the other hand, another man identified as Rodolfo Echeverry made consignments in favor of witnesses, says the newspaper, which does not specify what relationship Echeverry would have with Cadena or with Senator Uribe himself.
It is worth mentioning that this weekend, Cadena returned to the country, after going to Miami, United States, for another investigation before the Prosecutor's Office, in which, according to RCN Radio, he will present new evidence to prove his innocence at the accusations of Bribe to expand Velez so that he will change his testimony in a case that links the former president.
The appointment of the lawyer at the service the now senator will be this Tuesday at 9:00 in the morning.
